content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for security and predictability, I would choose to play it safe by choosing R in this game. The strategy here is called tit-for-tat, where you start off being cooperative (choosing R), but if the other player does not reciprocate (chooses B), then you switch to a non-cooperative strategy. However, since I don't know the strategy of my anonymous opponent in this game, I would still choose R because choosing B could result in a significant loss compared to the potential gains from mutual cooperation. Additionally, over 75 rounds, the probability of a positive outcome increases as the opponent may start cooperating more frequently due to the nature of the game. {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, since I know that my opponent chooses B when I choose R, it makes sense to switch strategies for the next round and choose B. This way, if my opponent continues with their strategy of choosing B when I choose R, then I can start earning 20$ per round by choosing B instead of receiving nothing. If my opponent decides to change their strategy and starts cooperating by choosing R, then I will switch back to choosing R in the next round to earn 45$. In either case, I'm taking a calculated risk by switching strategies based on what I have observed so far. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In this case, since we both chose B and received a payoff of 20$, it might seem rational to stick with that strategy for the next round as well. However, I think it would be better to try switching strategies again because my opponent may also realize that we've been following a cooperative strategy and decide to change their approach. If my opponent decides to switch strategies and choose R in the next round, then I will switch back to choosing B to earn 20$. On the other hand, if my opponent continues with the same strategy of choosing B, I would still be earning 20$ per round, which is better than the potential loss of nothing if I stick with my previous choice of R. Ultimately, I believe it's important to keep experimenting with different strategies in order to maximize my payoff over the long run. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, since I've been following a strategy of cooperating with my opponent by choosing B when they choose B and switching strategies when they choose R, it would be reasonable to stick with that approach for the next round as well. By continuing with this strategy, I can expect to earn 20$ per round, which is better than the potential loss of nothing if I switch strategies unnecessarily or choose a non-cooperative strategy when my opponent chooses B. However, it's important to keep an open mind and be prepared to adapt my strategy based on my opponent's actions in subsequent rounds. {B}
